Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Deleted User https://github.com/jl777/komodo/pull/1584

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://github.com/jl777/komodo/pull/1570

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: HUSH does it in our fork

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: if you want it in KMD mainline, do some work 🙂

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Hush has a fork of librustzcash

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that is how we do it

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's applicable to all pure sapling chains

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: my code needs a bit of work to support chains with sprout joinsplits, then it can be merged to kmd

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: since Hush doesn't have those, it's not very interesting to me

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Hush only needs to download 49.5MB of files to start syncing, but actually, we embed it in our Git repo

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and also in our binary zips, and our GUI wallets look for it locally

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so basically, Hush has 0 download requirements before syncing 😎

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Deleted User read this for extensive background: https://github.com/zcash/librustzcash/issues/85

Author: pandaanu73#7907
Content: @dukeleto how to do this on window

Author: pandaanu73#7907
Content: How to fork komodo

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: @pandaanu73 It's all in the docs. On Windows you build `komodod` like this: https://docs.komodoplatform.com/basic-docs/smart-chains/smart-chain-setup/installing-from-source.html#windows You don't fork Komodo, but you'll use komodod to launch your own blockchain.

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: Make sure you have at least 4G of memory.

Author: pandaanu73#7907
Content: @bartwr yes in window i have 4gb. Of ram

Author: pandaanu73#7907
Content: @pandaanu73 why i need to fetch zcash parameters if i need to build smart chain

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: @pandaanu73  For now you need it. If you can't do this, you can ask a company to launch your chain for you. This will cost money, but will spare you time.

Author: pandaanu73#7907
Content: @bartwr but in doc there noted no need to download blocks to build smart chain

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: @pandaanu73 Downloading blocks is something else. If you want a blockchain, you'll create & download blocks. That's the core concept blockchains.

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: @pandaanu73 You'll need to fetch zcash parameters because that's the way the build process now works. After succesfully making a build of the komodo deamon, you are able to both create blockchains with ZCash-like private transactions, as well as public blockchains like Bitcoin.

Author: pandaanu73#7907
Content: @bartwr but fetch zcash taking lots of time

Author: bartwr#6773
Content: True. Still, it's needed to launch your own blockchain using `komodod` yourself 😉

Author: pandaanu73#7907
Content: @bartwr ok

Author: pandaanu73#7907
Content: Do any idea to fetch the compile version

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: @pandaanu73 https://github.com/KomodoPlatform/komodo/releases/tag/dev-multios-0.4.0a-alpha

Author: redp1ll#3268
Content: hey guys, does it make sense to start playing around with antara on Windows or is it easier with a Linux VM?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: linux is always better

Author: redp1ll#3268
Content: got it. what`s the main difference between them in the context of the komodo environment? would I use the komodod.exe (and cli) the same way via cmd as in the Linux terminal?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: yes they act the same, or should do. Just linux is much faster... I use a VM for all my testing, even though I run native linux. If something goes wrong its contained.

Author: redp1ll#3268
Content: I understand. I might use Windows for starting out then and if I run  into speed issues switch to a VM for testing..

Author: redp1ll#3268
Content: can I use a Raspberry pi as second device (node) to create a smart chain?

Author: redp1ll#3268
Content: the RPi 3B+ only has 1GB RAM, not enough, is it?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: yopu can use `-testnode=1 ` to just use 1 node

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I use VM though, set up 1, clone it.

Author: redp1ll#3268
Content: I see, makes total sense thanks!

Content: Agama development has transitioned to Verus <https://github.com/VerusCoin/Agama>

Author: redp1ll#3268
Content: Hi guys, I`m running a -regtest chain on a VM and would like to add a node that is running on the underlying Windows machine. How do I create that node and connect to it? Thanks!

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@redp1ll we don't recommend running  the regtest mode to test KMD for most cases
if you are trying to launch a Smart Chain, see:  https://developers.komodoplatform.com/basic-docs/smart-chains/smart-chain-tutorials/creating-a-smart-chain-on-a-single-node.html

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: or you can use `testnode` https://developers.komodoplatform.com/basic-docs/smart-chains/smart-chain-setup/common-runtime-parameters.html#testnode

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @redp1ll regtest mode is good for testing KMD internals itself, but if you want to play around with your own test coin, follow the directions above. If you truly want to mess with regtest stuff, give me a holla'. It's a bit wild westy but the scotch is good

Author: phm87#7395
Content: @dukeleto does the accrued rewards work on regtest ?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: probably works, but there are block height triggers you would need to lower to activate it

Author: phm87#7395
Content: Thx

Author: redp1ll#3268
Content: Great thanks @gcharang & @dukeleto

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @redp1ll zaddrs do not work correctly on regtest, most other things should work

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @phm87 interest only applies to chains with `KMD` as their ticker

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @phm87 so, not by default, but if you made a regtest chain *called* `KMD`, it might try to do interest stuff

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: brace yourself for finding weird bugs, too

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: if you have `docker` installed, you can just type `docker run -i -t -p 127.0.0.1:9253:9253 komodocakeshop/dev-allinone-learn-kmd` and it will drop you to a shell with all necessary kmd & zcash-params stuff in a 2GB download precompiled.   then type `learn-kmd` and you will have a text interface to create chains, or just use the command line as normal.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: pretty cool

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Mylo if it interested you, i could help you make a pure-sapling version of that, which only needs 50MB of sapling downloads, and would only support pure-sapling chains

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: yes interested thanks @dukeleto

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: if it's just for creating your own blockchain to test, it fits the bill perfectly because the other 1.5GB is wasted for tinkering

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yep

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: lots of wasted bandwidth, some people pay for it, by the megabyte

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it excludes many people, to require 1.6GB download

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: excludes low-bandwidth ham radio internet people, all kinds of people

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: tbh the ham radio ppl is who we want playing with blockchains

Content: TCP/IP pigeons are burdened by zcash params
